Award.AwardTitle: Workforce Development: Graduate Data Science Workshop & Community Building

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Washington will host a national workshop where graduate students in data science disciplines will interact to explore data science grand challenges in a collaborative environment. The project will implement a novel idea and advance the understanding of how to develop data science communities by engaging graduate students, academia, and industry. It also addresses an important national need for researchers with cross-disciplinary training in data science and serves as a catalyst for other institutions to integrate data science skills more broadly throughout the curriculum.

The goal of the project is to help create a highly connected workforce that is adept at cross-disciplinary communication and idea synthesis, primed to solve a new generation of data science and big data challenges. To accomplish this goal, the investigators will conduct a 2.5-day workshop for approximately 100 attendees that is designed to (1) introduce graduate students to new data science concepts and applications, (2) enable students to interact with experts from industry, domain, and methodology fields, and (3) initiate the establishment of a professional community using team building activities. The investigators will conduct a pre-workshop promotional campaign and develop a web site where users can connect and share their ideas. Following the workshop, a set of white papers, team reports, and a workshop report will be available to the public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project created a community of practice at the graduate level around Data Science across all disciplines from across the country.  The community was built around a web site that allowed for sharing, commenting on and evaluation of White Papers describing a novel use of Data Science in a domain or a new Data Science method.  The White Papers were sent out for external review under the NSF Graduate Research Fellowships Program review guidelines.  The top 100 reviewed White Paper authors were invited to participate in the 2015 NSF Graduate Data Science Workshop in Seattle at the University of Washington on August 5-7. During the workshop, participants engaged in breakout sessions seeking to define the grand challenges around Data Science adoption across disciplines.  They worked with faculty from University of Washington, Fred Hutch Cancer Research Center, and professionals from companies like Google and Microsoft. During the next 12 months, the participants continued to work on project ideas they developed during the workshop. In 2016, the most productive 20 of the original participant pool were invited back for the 2016 NSF Graduate Data Science which included participants from regional training grants aligned with the Data Science education goal. During this workshop, the participants created their own breakout sessions topics to target problems in their discipline and domains.  They also received training on how to be successful when perusing academic, industry, or national lab jobs as a Data Scientist in addition to sessions focused around diversity and ethics. The teams formed during these workshops still exist and continue to function even as participants move on to industry, academic and government roles.


Last Modified: 05/25/2017
Modified by: David A Beck

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project created a community of practice at the graduate level around Data Science across all disciplines from across the country. The community was built around a web site that allowed for sharing, commenting on and evaluation of White Papers describing a novel use of Data Science in a domain or a new Data Science method. The White Papers were sent out for external review under the NSF Graduate Research Fellowships Program review guidelines. The top 100 reviewed White Paper authors were invited to participate in the 2015 NSF Graduate Data Science Workshop in Seattle at the University of Washington on August 5-7. During the workshop, participants engaged in breakout sessions seeking to define the grand challenges around Data Science adoption across disciplines. They worked with faculty from University of Washington, Fred Hutch Cancer Research Center, and professionals from companies like Google and Microsoft. During the next 12 months, the participants continued to work on project ideas they developed during the workshop. In 2016, the most productive 20 of the original participant pool were invited back for the 2016 NSF Graduate Data Science which included participants from regional training grants aligned with the Data Science education goal. During this workshop, the participants created their own breakout sessions topics to target problems in their discipline and domains. They also received training on how to be successful when perusing academic, industry, or national lab jobs as a Data Scientist in addition to sessions focused around diversity and ethics. The teams formed during these workshops still exist and continue to function even as participants move on to industry, academic and government roles.
